reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: THIS GAME IS NOT FOR THE LIGHT OF HEART OR THE IMPATIENT
IF YOU WANT A FEATURE COMPLETE EXPERIENCE, THIS GAME IS NOT IT RIGHT NOW, THAT IS WHAT EARLY ACCESS IS FOR.
ALSO, PVP IS ENABLED EVERYWHERE AT ALL TIMES, SO BE CAREFUL. HOWEVER, PERMA-DEATH IS NOT AN ISSUE AT THIS TIME
Divergence Online aims to be an MMORPG in the vein of traditional games, most especially Star Wars Galaxies (Especially Star Wars Galaxies). The game, as it advertises, takes a lot of inspiration for mechanics and assets from the game prior to the New Game Experience Update. The game bases its skill system around a single skill window which is divided into numerous professions. For example,  the Artisan Profession is the builder and crafter profession of the game, and Medics are the healers.

So far, the game is limited to its barest essentials, this being:
Resource Gathering (With varying qualities and having to scan for resources), Crafting (Influenced by the resource qualities), basic combat (Punching, Handguns, Assault Rifles, Shotguns and Sniper RIfles) and the ability to build structures. Basically, only the Artisan Profession is functional as of writing this review, I could be wrong.

There are a wide selection of races (Species) in the game right now, divided between the different societies they come from. At the time of wiriting this review, the races currently have no differences statistically whatsoever, and are only aesthetic, apart from Synthetics, which can transfer their conciousness between any bodies they come across that are unoccupied. There is a video about customisation created by Ethan Casner if you wish to know more about the lore of each race in the setting.

When it comes to resource gathering and crafting, you will first need to train in the Artisan profession. You will be given a Resouce Scanning Tool and your basic Crafting Tool. First, so that you know what you're looking for, you look at the crafting tool to find your first clothes. Yes, you start in your underwear right now if you aren't a synthetic. Once you find what you want to make, you will need to go to your resource scanner tool and search for what you want in the lift, click it, click scan and follow the percentages. Once you get far enough, you will start to be able to make personal harvesters which will actually collecte resources from the ground for you over time as long as you power it. This system is also used for creating the things you need for building structures.

You can build structures either from prefab materials in the crafting system or (If you subscribe to the game at $10 US a month) you will be given access to a voxel building tool which is much more complex than the likes of Minecraft. There are even a few premade structures (such as a Cantina and a City Hall). All structures in the game world are destructible. This includes harvesters, generators and the buildings and hoppers necessary for building.

The way that combat works in Divergence is through an over the shoulder shooter system. You must aim and fire to hit and kill your target. In combat, there are a few options. Guns are implemented and combat is very raw right now. It works fine, but needs expansion. There are a variety of firearms of the typical niches, such as shotguns, assault rifles, handguns and sniper rifles, but not much else. There aren't any NPCs fully functional in the game at the time of writing, but they will be implemented VERY soon. So at the moment, combat is exclusively between players.

Visually speaking, the style is the game is amazing in my opinion. It stands out very well and the world is very well made. It is also fairly large. I have roamed quite a large area and haven't explored the whole available play space. Though, at the moment there is not much reason to explore out there apart from in the desert at the time of writing, as there are valuable resources there.

Divergence Online, as you can see, is a one time purchase game. However, the game does offer an optional subscription that offers a few benefits. The subscription rate is $10 US every month.

At the moment, buying the game will give you a single character slot. This may change in the future, however, at this point in time, you only have one. Subscribing will allow you multiple character slots and will allow you access to the ferrocrete tool, a voxel based building tool. Think of it like Minecraft but with the ability to save out surfaces from existing blocks. This system does not give you any inherent advantage in gameplay, it simply is another way to build. Another system you gain access to when subscribing is terraforming (Which I am not sure if it is in the game right now). This will allow you to mould the land to a degree.

It may also be noted that there are special packages available on the website for purchase right now that give special perks. Starting at $120 US, you will be given access in each one to special benefits. Such as special races, these include:
The one time creation of an uncloneable Vindicator or Verrator character of the Veli race
The Ennie, a species of small humanoid lizards.

Other options include the ability to get a head start with a synthetic character, givign you access to a combat chassis from the get go, or a military chassis (Basically a mech body). These two items will be able to be earnt in game however, they are just a head start through this means.

Another benefit available from these packs is access to a special account bound PERMANENT ferrocrete tool, which you will not need subscription to use. Essentially you get a lifetime subscription.

The last most expensive option is to pay for your own custom land mass in the game, this being $1000 US. They will build your island in accordance to your specifications. This option I personally do not recommend unless you are feeling generous (Or are some crazy millionaire).

If you purchase any of these packages, you will need to speak to Ethan Casner through any of the possible means and he will help you redeem your purchase. The island thing will most likely take a while, if you're crazy enough for that.


Overall, Divergence Online is in the very, very, VERY EARLY STAGES of development. If you are interested in the game like I am, and have been since I discovered it being tried to be built years ago, I can only recommend you buy the game. The community is very friendly and we all commune on the official teamspeak server, which can be found on the official facebook page and numerous other places. However, you will be understood if you do not want to buy the game yet. Just do understand that Early Access is for unfinished products, and this game is a good example of this.

DO NOT go in expecting a remotely finished game and you will be pleased with the game and its steady progress. THe game is patched on a pretty much daily basis and we are getting more features and bugfixes daily.

Ultimately:

I do recommend the game for those who wish to support a potential SWG successor and are willing to wait for the game to be built up, and don't mind helping to fund the developers.

If you do not have the patience to wait for the game to be built up around you, it is not recommended. If what I have said hasn't convinced you, you should definitely come look back regularly to see if you change your mind.

Like with all things, if you want this game to be good, patience is key.

TL:DR version -
Positive aspects:
+ beautiful game environment
+ robust crafting/mining system
+ robust base/home building system with the ability to use voxel tools
+ consistent updates ( in my experience since starting the game)
+real time/non turn based combat , healing
+ good in game community/active devs, GMs
+ original race concepts (synths for example)
+ Solid performance, 60 FPS on highest settings with medium draw distance.  Drops a bit when entering populated cities (my cpu is a bottle neck in this case >.<)

Negative aspects
- feature incomplete (this is not unexpected-it is an EA after all!)
- steam community/forums for the game semi-toxic
- PvE - mobs are currently bugged out, and are to be fixed

Points to take note of:
~ Recreated SWG assets. (not ripped from the game, but modeled after and used in the game)
~ Similar skill system to SWG
~ Real time, third person view combat.
~ Mining/Crafting Similar to SWG
~ Full PVP world

Long version
This review on the game is based on having played the game after 54 or so hours based upon steam's estimation.

I will start by saying that the term SWG 2.0 is a bit misleading.  Because to say this implies to me that this game and it's price tag are just a product of a few people trying to cash in on graphically prettier version of Star Wars Galaxies, and call it a day.   The more fitting term that I would go with, as coined by those who described Repopulation would be a, Spiritual successor" to SWG.

Now granted

So, if you are really serious about supporting the development of a truely free roaming sandbox game then I recomend you stump up the money and help out by getting stuck in. However even this might leave you a little frustrated at the moment as there aren't any road maps or dev logs to see what is being worked on. I belive the game has HUGE potential but the dev team needs to work quickly to get some basics in place e.g. groups, maps, trading, professions, private messaging, and some story/quest content. From on old SWG explorer and resource gatherer point of view Divergence is everything you want it to be but that's only going to last so long without the other elements of a sandbox mmo. It could also use a combat flag option even though I have to say I am finding the risk element of potentially getting killed and my inventory looted quick exciting !
It's got a long way to go but maybe it can succeed where others have failed, the dev approach is unorthodox but maybe that's what's needed, less corporate 'Build a game to make money' and a bit more 'build a game that is someone's passion'......

I've been following the development of Divergence: Online for some time, and believed in the concept enough that I backed it prior to its availability on Steam. So, how does it stack up now that we all have access to it? First, some definitions.

Early Access Does Not Mean Finished Game
The game is in Early Access. Valve intended this program to be a kind of crowdfunding where people who liked the concept of a game enough could throw money into a development pot so that the developers could finish the game. In return, they gained access before the game was ready for a general audience. As such, reviews can't be made on the state of the game, but rather on the pace and quality of development. This is particularly true when the game has only been in Early Access for two weeks, as is the case here.

With that in mind, here's my review.

Pace of Development
Since the game launched in Early Access, we have seen almost daily updates to the game, and each one is substantial. Major bugs are fixed or mitigated, new features are added, and feedback from the community is addressed. The pace of development is very rapid. This inevitably means that new bugs are also being introduced daily, but at this point in the game's life, a plethora of bugs is to be expected.

Quality of Development
So how about the quality of development? Well, I can't see the code or the server performance graphs, so I have to judge this based on the rate of improvement, not just the rate of development. Visually, the game is not progressing very much. It looks better than SWG did, but it has a long way to go to be complete. A lot of the graphics are placeholders pulled from or based on SWG assets. That does nothing to solidify the game's own feel, and this is an issue the developers have promised to address. I believe they're sincere. Whether they can deliver or not remains to be seen. From a systems perspective, the game is improving by leaps and bounds on a very rapid basis. In the past few days, we gained full-loot for PvP, a lot system, new mobs, a ton of new craftable interior modules, bigger harvesters, and others. Network performance has improved, though not as much as systems have.

The Community
The community growing up around this game is fantastic. Almost everyone is willing to help each other. It being a full-loot open world PvP game, I imagine you'll start to see the usual roving gangs common to games of this type, but for now at least most people are cooperating. Interestingly, the community on the Steam forums seems much more toxic than the community actually in the game or on the Facebook group.

Is it SWG?
Not exactly. It borrows a lot of the features, yes. Crafting and harvesting are extremely reminiscent of pre-CU SWG. Combat is nothing like pre-CU, CU, or NGE combat, however. D:O combat is unique, and twitch-based. A lot of supporting systems from SWG are not yet in the game, such as missions or image design. However, this is probably the closest thing we're going to get to a SWG 2 in our lifetimes. It's certainly closer than The Repopulation was.

A Lack of PR
The one area where this game really falls down is in public relations. The developers need to improve how they deal with the public. I understand they're under a lot of stress, but the image they present is somewhat less than professional. Sometimes this is reflected in the game itself, with game text being just a little too snarky or even immersion-breaking. Thankfully, this is nothing that can't be fixed fairly easily. If they can bring on even a part-time community manager, a lot of this will be solved.

Final Thoughts
The game is very rough, with many key systems partially implemented, buggy, or outright missing. But we're two weeks into Early Access, and the game is already vastly superior to where it was at launch. The developers know what they're doing, but are in need of a community manager. The community for the game is the reason you should buy into Early Access right now rather than waiting. This game is going to be amazing six months down the road, but the community is amazing now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello all, my name is Wheelpi Efaava inside the wonderful universe of Divergence Online, while I understand that lately people have been giving the game a bit of a rough edged review, allow me to take the time to explain this game. When we made gameizle, a community site to help catalog the game info and help new players understand, we realized the sheer size and scope of this game. So let our crew have a chance to bring light to our new game of passion.
First out of the gate, lets touch on what is Alpha? Alpha stage in itself is a treat for any heavy gaming enthusiast, you have the pleasure of watching the game grow from nothing into something, to provide crucial feedback to help everything keep going forward.

That being stated, lets look at the crucial elements we have all come to expect from mmo's, the community itself and at large is outstanding. It offers direct lines of communication with the games creator Ethan, lead programmer Ava and game master DeathFyre, at no time has any complaint gone un answered, no matter how tiny the matter might be.
As for character customization, everyone likes to change it up, this game yet again does not fail to set the bar for customization to another level. Being able to command every aspect of your character from eye color, down to the shape of their leg muscles, it brings what I was looking for in a large way.  With different species of humans, aliens, elementals to cyborgs, this game takes the standards for diversity to a new standard we hope stays with the game through to release, if not more! In a game with minimal HUD and no name plate 24/7 it gives the user the ability to stand out even more.

Lets look at crafting, crafting and more crafting, not in the typical uselessness that most games have dumbed it down to either. It is all for a purpose, its for experience, custom designed structures ( that's right, design your heart out! ), upgraded weapons, armor and more! For those of you out there who miss the old star wars galaxy, this game has grand slammed this aspect far out of the park with recreating it in stunningly accurate detail and gone above for a third time in making it encompass even the resistances/conditions of materials.

Which brings us to collection of resources, surveying, with the scenery that this game engine generates, with no instancing, is stunning and breathtaking. You will find yourself losing track of what your doing climbing mountains, walking rivers, exploring jungles and marshes. All on the hunt to find the best resources currently available, with the resources on a randomization system it ensures for hours of gameplay and community emersion.

Our last area was player vs player, this game draws the sandbox genre with a 24/7 pvp is always active aspect, which lands on a mixed playing field. They have done stupendous with balancing it in recent patch's and plans in the future for more, it is promising to make it to launch a very well polished system which we eagerly await. This does however put your structures in danger 24/7 as well, so it challenges you to a level of lurking in the shadows squirling away your gotten gains.

All things considered, with the modest price tag of 30 dollars, we could not have been more pleased, they offer exactly what they sell. With the activity in development, the patch's being released, constant contact with game staff, we expect to see nothing but outstanding things from this game on its journey to release!

I Have been a backer of this project for over 3 years now and had access to the pre-Alpha, Alpha, and now am playing the early access(beta) on steam.  At the time of writing this I have over 110 hours played in this game. First a little info about my feelings on the previous versions of the game I have played.


PRE-ALPHA:

I got Access to Pre-Alpha about 3 days after it was available. In Pre-Alpha there was terraforming and a few models available for building, but not much more than that. I played around with the terraforming and built a few things, but ultimately didn't play much as there were no real features in game to test or play with other then terraforming.


ALPHA:

Fast forward about a year or so and I'm in alpha. Now we are on an all new game engine with better graphics, and a much more streamlined pipeline for development. Many bug fixes at a pace of about 4 patches a week some times more. Multiple new assets to play with, and now we have the survey tool, and general crafting tool to play with. I walked around the bare world looking for resources, and even crafted myself a set of cloths, a hopper, and one harvester just to check things out. At this time there wasn't many people playing, and the world was so empty I just lost interest after a few hours each day, and would go to another game to get my gaming fix on. A few months later Ethan did the ferrocrete tool stream on youtube, and I joined in to see the new features in game, and all the fixes. I wasn't able to get a tool at the time because I forgot to ask for one xD so after that stream I didn't play much more.

Early Access Review

I don't usually write reviews for games, but for this one I think it deserves me coming out of review writing retirement. I really enjoy it and feel like everyone who's looking for a game that resembles Star Wars Galaxies should definitely give this a shot.

I think the skill system is on point and I like the slow progression that it presents to the players. It's a game that takes dedication and planning on how you want your character to be build due to the limited number of skill points you get in order to level up skills available in different profession trees.

Also, the surveying and crafting system is amazing. There are a couple of problems here and there with the menus bugging out periodically, but its Alpha. The PvP combat is also very good as well and I like the way the gun system works. I am hoping to see more weapons in the future and can't wait for the mechs to be released into the game.

The graphics are also very well done, and look good even on the lowest settings which really surprised me. As of right now the options menu isn't really that filled with choices of things to mess with, but of course that will also change in the future so it isn't that bad of a thing.

I think the only thing I really did wish was present in the current state of the game was npcs so training professions involving weapons would be easier to level due to pvp being the only way right now to do that at all.

In the end, this game is amazing and if your anywhere near the fence on playing this game or thinking about it at all just go for it. It's worth the investment and you will sink many hours of your life into it and love every moment!

Ok, so let me start off by saying that if you enjoy simple games where you can get in and kill people without having to commit time and energy this is NOT the game for you. This game like it's predecessor SWG is a time sink that takes a large amount of time and dedication. You start off very small and you grow your skill level. It will be extremely hard and sometimes boring in the beginning if you are somebody who needs non stop action.

The good thing about this game is that it's a new game that is trying to adhere to a lot of standards set by an amazing game. If you want to be part of something amazing and join a great community then this is the place for you. It seems that a lot of people want to try and pick apart the fact that the game is a shell without a lot of content. That's completely true and this should be considered a pre alpha beta. If you think you are buying a complete game then stop and don't purchase. If you want to help have input in this project going forward please consider giving your time, money, and energy to help this project move forward. Also, join the divergence online group on Facebook to hear around the clock feedback from players and developers! This is the start of something great, you just need to be patient.
